title: Peace and Acceptance
content:
ThenewmoonsidianX's invitation compelled me to offer an alternative of my own. I didn't want to start an argument in his thread, so here's mine.

I'll stay simple too. As a very happy athiest, I'd like to invite everyone to consider my own philisophy. I only ask one thing. We all have the capacity to reason, although some people exercise it more than others. I want everyone use that capacity to the best of their ability. I'm asking you all to never take anything on faith.

I know that goes against what most of you have been taught from an early age. Many of you have been told that religion holds all the answers. Well, I want to tell you now that no one has all the answers, and that being old or widely believed doesn't make an idea true. Evidence is the only thing that we can rely on. Don't take my word for it, of course. Think it over.

Giving up on blind faith may seem very bleak. A lot of people have come to rely on the ideas that their parents and the church put into their head. If you were to give up the idea of a powerful protector and eternal life, it probably would be hard. But in my opinion, it's better to come to peace with the world as it is than to invent a crutch.

When I look at the world around me, I see elegance and beauty, the same as any Christian does. But I accept it on its own terms, as the amazing wonder it is. I don't disrespect it by telling myself that there is something greater just around the corner. Without an afterlife, I know the true value of life. Instead of viewing life as something to be endured before I get to the good part, I know not to waste it. Without ancient and unfounded morals warping my thoughts, I'm free to exercise reason and my innate morality (which you all have) to decide what is right. No one can tell me to hate.

If we, the human race, don't wise up soon, religion will tear the world apart. If we don't reject dogma and unprovable beliefs then it will always be more of the same. Religions will clash over their beliefs, but there will be no possibility for compromise. Religions will continue to persecute anyone who lives in a way they don't sanction. Everyone will be sure that their way is the only true way. But they won't have a reason, so there will be no discussion. Without reason, there can't be. Don't be a part of that. Please. You can be happy without a god, and without a god you're free to let everyone else be happy too.

Questions and discussion are, of course, welcome.________________

title: Re: Peace and Acceptance
content:
I've chosen to be an agnostic, since I've reasoned that no one can possibly tell whether a god exists or not - and, more importantly, that it doesn't matter.

Believing in a higher power seems right to us because it's etched deeply into our brain from way back when we all lived in packs and worshipped the alpha male. (This same pyschological relic is also the reason we blindly worship celebrities and people who we admire.)

title: Peace and Acceptance
content:
It's not just religion posing these problems, either. Blind faith in dictatorial leaders, magazine producers, and even the majority verdict on anything--who is to be trusted or hated, what to wear, what to say.

I don't believe anything I read, though I give much more credence to anything that isn't the mainstream media, and I certainly trust my own experiences which indicate that either the universe is an extension of me/us or vice versa, and thus the world reflects our thoughts, words and beliefs.

Thus, although as far as God is concerned I'm in the agnostic boat, I know there's something more to the world than we commonly accept. The point remains; don't believe everything you hear just because someone 'knowledgable' or 'important' said it.

Edit: I don't think agnostic would be the correct term. I'm inclined to believe there exists some underlying intelligence to the universe, however I don't feel that it is apart from us. Thus I don't believe in 'God' as some sort of detached overseer/creator, but as a shared/divisible consciousness that participates in z own creation. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

content:
I don't think that there are absolute morals. I do, however, know what I think is right, and I don't advocate turning a blind eye to what you think is wrong. It's very important to me that there be reasons behind my morals, even if it's something as simple as, "Is this how I want to be treated?"

The reason I think that having no religions is better than having many (or one) is because without dogmatic belief, everyone is (theoretically) open to discussion. You can't argue with "This is what I believe and anyone who disagrees is wrong and/or evil." A person who approaches their beliefs from that direction isn't going to be swayed, no matter how much sense you make. Not everyone would be reasonable even without religion, but every roadblock removed is a good thing. I realize that most religious people aren't that extreme, and many do question their beliefs at times, but many don't. They're the ones who make religion dangerous. The rest of you are only their camouflage.

My issue is not with religion specifically, but with not questioning everything as hard as possible, and not discarding what can't be proved. Religion is a major symptom of that, and, at the same time, perpetuates it.________________
